musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Chord?
musicTheoryContent.content: A chord is when you play three or more notes at the same time. The most common type of chord is the triad, which is made of a root, third, and fifth. Try playing C, E, and G on a keyboard – that’s a C major chord!
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Image of a C major chord on a keyboard and staff

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Key Signature?
musicTheoryContent.content: A key signature is a set of sharp (#) or flat (b) symbols at the beginning of a staff. It tells you which notes are always sharp or flat in a piece of music. For example, one sharp usually means you’re in the key of G major.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Image of a C major chord on a keyboard and staff

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Major Scale?
musicTheoryContent.content: A major scale is a sequence of notes with a specific pattern: whole, whole, half, whole, whole, whole, half. Try it on the piano starting at C – that’s the C major scale!
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Image of a C major chord on a keyboard and staff

musicTheoryContent.title: How Chords Fit in a Key
musicTheoryContent.content: In any key, there are chords built on each note. These chords usually follow a pattern: major, minor, minor, major, major, minor, diminished. In C major, that gives you C, Dm, Em, F, G, Am, Bdim.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Image of a C major chord on a keyboard and staff

musicTheoryContent.title: What is Musical Form?
musicTheoryContent.content: Musical form is how music is organized. Common forms include ABA (ternary) and AABA. It’s like a musical roadmap that tells you what comes next.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Diagram showing AABA song structure

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Refrain?
musicTheoryContent.content: A refrain is a section of music that repeats throughout a song, like a chorus. It’s often the most memorable part!
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Diagram showing AABA song structure

musicTheoryContent.title: Theme and Variation
musicTheoryContent.content: This form starts with a simple theme, then repeats it with changes each time. Think of it like decorating the same cake in different ways.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Diagram showing AABA song structure

musicTheoryContent.title: What is Rhythm?
musicTheoryContent.content: Rhythm is the pattern of sounds and silences in music. It tells you when to play or stay quiet. It’s what makes music feel like it has a beat.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Graphic showing whole, half, and quarter notes with beat counts

musicTheoryContent.title: Understanding Time Signatures
musicTheoryContent.content: A time signature is like a musical clock. It tells you how many beats are in a measure and what kind of note gets one beat. 4/4 means 4 beats per measure, and the quarter note gets one beat.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Graphic showing whole, half, and quarter notes with beat counts

musicTheoryContent.title: Note Values: Whole, Half, Quarter
musicTheoryContent.content: A whole note lasts for 4 beats, a half note for 2, and a quarter note for 1. Think of it like cutting a pie – whole is the full pie, half is half, and quarter is one slice out of four.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Graphic showing whole, half, and quarter notes with beat counts

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Beat?
musicTheoryContent.content: The beat is the steady pulse you feel in music – like a ticking clock or your heartbeat. Most songs follow a steady beat to keep everything together.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Graphic showing whole, half, and quarter notes with beat counts

musicTheoryContent.title: What is Sheet Music?
musicTheoryContent.content: Sheet music is a written version of a song using symbols. It tells musicians what notes to play, how fast, and how loud or soft.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Timeline showing early chant notation to modern sheet music

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Clef?
musicTheoryContent.content: A clef is a symbol at the beginning of a staff that tells you which notes go where. The treble clef is for higher notes, and the bass clef is for lower notes.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Timeline showing early chant notation to modern sheet music

musicTheoryContent.title: How Music Notation Evolved
musicTheoryContent.content: Long ago, music was passed down by ear. Over time, symbols were created to write down notes, rhythms, and more. That’s how modern sheet music was born.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Timeline showing early chant notation to modern sheet music

musicTheoryContent.title: Reading a Staff
musicTheoryContent.content: The staff is made of 5 lines and 4 spaces. Each line or space represents a note. The clef helps you know which note is which.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Labeled staff diagram showing clef, measures, bar lines

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Measure?
musicTheoryContent.content: A measure is a section of the staff that holds a certain number of beats, based on the time signature. It helps organize the rhythm.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Labeled staff diagram showing clef, measures, bar lines

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Bar Line?
musicTheoryContent.content: Bar lines are vertical lines that divide the staff into measures. They help you keep track of where you are in the music.
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Labeled staff diagram showing clef, measures, bar lines

musicTheoryContent.title: What is a Major Scale?
musicTheoryContent.content: A major scale is a sequence of notes with a specific pattern: whole, whole, half, whole, whole, whole, half. Try it on the piano starting at C – that’s the C major scale!
musicTheoryContent.visual_description: Image of a C major chord on a keyboard and staff
